Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2015 08:28PM DianaNM wrote: Just finished the Outlander series. The woman is a doctor, goes back in time, and thinks maggots are great! All the medical stuff was very interesting.
Posts.Title: A rad onc weighs in on radiation "burns" Spinnerpom 53nancy

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2015 11:34PM DianaNM wrote: eugnid, that ncbi study certainly gives pause. This decision is killing me right now. I am having a lumpectomy on Thursday, and then will shortly have to decide. I had a mastectomy the first time, mostly to avoid the decision, but I am built so that I lost most of my lymph nodes to the mastectomy. Would like to have one "good" side. I keep going back to the fact that radiation causes cancer. How is the radiation therapy different from other types of radiation, the ones that cause cancer? I have had more than my share of radiation exposure, actually worked at a nuclear weapons plant for a year that has a class action award for former employees that have been diagnosed with cancer. I am five days short in qualifying for the award. I blame my first crazy tumor on wearing my iPhone on my purse strap, the new one I blame on many hours with my iPad on my lap with wifi on. There are other factors of course, but my gut feeling is very strong about this. So I am between, hell no, not more radiation! And the recurrence numbers I know will be quoted.
Posts.Title: A rad onc weighs in on radiation "burns" Spinnerpom 53nancy

Posts.Content: DianaNM wrote: Had a right MX on 5/21, no recon. Made a point of asking the surgeon beforehand about the number of nodes he would take for testing, he said sentinel and one more. If they were clear, he would stop there. After surgery, he told DH and I that he had only taken two nodes. I've got a big mess under my arm, inflamed scar tissue has formed a ditch, and there's sort of a tire of swelling between that and my underarm. Was told to go to Lymphedema PT, so had my first appointment this morning. She noticed some infection in the bad area, so back to the doctor, where I picked up a copy of my pathology report. The report says 0/16 nodes were tested. So I asked the CNP about it. Something about when the doctor went for the clear margins, he took the breast tissue over to the side, where there was a lot of yellow fat. I am 5'4" and weigh 160 pounds, so there was a little fat, but not that unusual. And the nodes were blue from the injections. My tumor was not to the side, it was 2.5 cm at the 10 o'clock position just above my nipple. So now I am clearly at risk for lymphadema. How does this happen? And how did the surgeon not realize he removed an extra 14 nodes? I mean if he realized it, wouldn't he have told me about it? I guess not, because when I saw him for a followup he had gotten the report back and still didn't mention it. I just cried all the way home. Can anyone give me a reasonable explanation for this?      Dx 4/17/2012, IDC, Right, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 0/16 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 5/21/2012 Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Right Dx 6/2/2015, IDC, Left, <1cm, Stage IA, Grade 1, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- (FISH) Surgery 6/18/2015 Lumpectomy; Lymph node removal: Sentinel Radiation Therapy 7/22/2015 Multi-catheter: Breast Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Surgeon said 0/2 nodes, Pathology report says 0/16! DianaNM jacee

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 08:03AM DianaNM wrote: I did go to Lymphedema PT yesterday. Didn't get far with it because after a couple of the stretches the wound in my "ditch" started to ooze so we stopped and I headed to the Dr office. Now I'm on keflex. Wondering how long I need to wait to try those stretches again. I'm supposed to go for a fitting tomorrow to get a compression sleeve and glove for traveling, and see if there is anything that can help the swelling on my trunk in my armpit. Interesting copay yesterday. Because the PT office was considered part of the hospital, I had to make a "hospital outpatient facility" copay of $75. And I'm supposed to go back once a week! If it were a clinic, my copay would be in the $25-$35 range. Now I've got to find another PT facility with a lymphedema specialist. My insurance is BCBS Federal. Can't afford another $300 a month in copays right now.

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2012 07:16PM DianaNM wrote: Thanks Jacee and dithmn for the explanation of the fatty pad. That does make a little more sense, but still doesn't help me figure out why the surgeon didn't mention any of this. I guess he was waiting for my Onco to tell me. It says that the nodes were in the anxillary tail, and that most were bisected, some were trisected. Does that sound like the fat pad? He also told me that I was still Stage II, and that seemed to be good news. The report does not look that good. My Nottingham stage is a 7-8, with a Mitotic count of 3. Guess I will be hearing more about that from my Onco too, appointment next week. After figuring that out, I'm not so focused on my missing nodes right now.
Posts.Title: Surgeon said 0/2 nodes, Pathology report says 0/16! DianaNM jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2012 02:36PM DianaNM wrote: Hi Raych. The Oncotest gives you a score to let you know how much chemo would benefit you. Since you have already had chemo, I don't know how much good it would do you. Did you have positive nodes? I was able to avoid rads by having a mastectomy instead of a lumpectomy. Really, you might want to consider a second opinion on that.
Posts.Title: Another Oncotype question mary71 Scarlet2

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2012 08:44AM DianaNM wrote: OK, for the OP. There is a chart on the Oncotest report called "Node Negative, ER-Positive Breast Cancer Chemotherapy Benefit". Because my score was in the mid range (25), and PR positive % was high, it shows a negative chemo benefit for scores in the mid range (18-30). But it looks like if your score is over 31, chemo would decrease distant recurrance by almost 30%.  So I think it was worth getting the test.
Posts.Title: Another Oncotype question mary71 Scarlet2

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2012 07:10AM DianaNM wrote: The first time I met with my MO, she said no Oncotype test. Because of my 99% positive ER score (70% PR), I guess. At the time, my tumor was measured at 2.3 cm.  After surgery it was at 2.5 cm with the highest mitotic score. Don't know if it grew. The surgeon offered to order the Oncotype test. It came back at 25, right in the middle.  I see my MO next week. Guess I will have some decisions to make.  None of this is easy, is it? I thought MX without recon would be pretty easy to recover from, but that has not been the case. I'm pretty terrified of chemo because of my history of problems with meds, and again the HT. But I know I'm going to need to give those a good shot.
Posts.Title: Another Oncotype question mary71 Scarlet2

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2012 12:23PM - edited Apr 30, 2012 07:38AM by DianaNM Bev, I am 59 and making the same decisions you are. I have not told my surgeon yet that I don't want reconstruction, but I'm hoping he doesn't react like yours did! He wanted to call the PS in when I saw him last week, but I declined. My onco is completely on board, and told me she is "the boss of the surgeon". lol You should follow your instincts. Only you know how well you do with general anesthesia (longer surgery for recon), wound healing, pain, etc. And how you would like having one fake boob!

The sentinel node is the one that the dye flows to first from the breast, but it's still a lymph node.

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2012 12:49PM DianaNM wrote: I didn't have reconstruction, pretty sure that sped up my drain removal time too. Went shopping today to look for vests. I found ONE Liz Caiborne sleeveless vest type thing with pockets over the breast area. When I got home, my fiber fill foob had come in the mail. We had to cut it down, but it is now pinned in the vest and I am ready to go to the grocery store! So excited! They are hanging low, but at least they are hanging.

There's a lot of swelling under my arm, and it developed into cellulitis and an infection. I wanted an antibiotic IV to get RID of it, but am on oral meds. At least it isn't getting worse. I hate taking meds, but best get used to it. The worst of it is, I am foregoing my nightly glass of wine in hope that these meds will do their job quicker. I was having trouble sleeping because of the assorted pains from the area, but last night I took 3mg of melatonin and slept for 10 hours! Boy, do I feel better today.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2012 11:40AM DianaNM wrote: DC, I want some knitted knockers! I can't figure out what I am going to do with my one flat side. Should be getting my drains out tomorrow. When my surgeon stopped by to "sign" me, my husband and I were laughing about something. Can't remember what, but the surgeons' expression was sort of like "you don't see THAT everyday". Right, I remember nothing after being wheeled into the surgery room and shifting to the operating bed. Out like a light. Here's a sentinel node shot story, which is the thing I was probably most worried about. It's the first thing they did. On the phone, the pre-op nurse told me it didn't hurt. The nurse that morning admitted that it could hurt a bit. In fact, she said the doctor doesn't talk much because one woman actually made him cry. Apparently, he told a woman that it wouldn't hurt, and she screamed at him. Something along the lines of "let's stick some needles in your boob and see how you like it!"  Actually, with the numbing spray, there was barely a sting with the shots. I made sure to tell him it wasn't bad.
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 06:10AM DianaNM wrote: ValFl, that sounds very scary! I agree, your immune system is compromised and it's easier to catch other stuff.  Speaking of which, I'm feeling like my surgeon lied to me. Before surgery, we talked about nodes and he told me he would take 2, and if they were clear that was it. AFTER surgery, he told my husband that he took 2 and they were clear. A week later at my checkup he'd gottent he path report and he said nodes are clear, you're still stage 2, go to PT, I'll see you in 3-4 months.  Picked up a copy of my path report yesterday and he took 16 nodes. No wonder my armpit is such a mess. I have a wound between two swollen masses that isn't healing well. When the PT had me do some stretches it started weeping, so now I'm on antibiotics. That probably wasn't the worst news on the report though. Don't know what it all means yet, but my Nottingham score (SBR) is a 7-8/9. Will find out more next week, but right now my mood is very down. Woke up at 4 this morning and couldn't go back to sleep, worrying about my missing lymph nodes. Which isn't doing me any good!
Posts.Title: May 2012 Mastectomies? Still_Snarky Fearlessfoot

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2012 10:17AM DianaNM wrote: Hi Kristin, I think 17 is a lot to recover from. You need to learn about how to avoid Lymphedema too. I am in the same boat, 16 removed but with no signs of cancer. Most of them were in my "breast tail".  Markat, I know how you feel. DH and I were eating dinner out a couple of days ago, and I felt I was in a daze. Told him I'm so sick of going to doctors, researching cancer, thinking about cancer. And I'm just starting, really. It could also be that the antibiotics I am on are making me depressed. I'm looking forward to a trip to Napa Valley in October. And a 25th anniversay cruise to Alaska at the end of May 2013. And figuring out what to do with myself (besides work) when my only child moves to Boston early next year to be with her boyfriend. My DH has hobbies, I need hobbies.
